page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY INCE BLUNDELL
page.content:
The word "Ince" probably refers to an island (in a marsh). Blundell comes from the name of the lords of the manor, who came here with William the Conqueror. One is mentioned in the Battle Abbey roll of 1094.
In the early l2th Century Ince was included in the Barony of Warrington. In early documents it is often referred to as three separate townships; Lady Green, Carr Houses and Ince Blundell. The l844 map clearly shows this and the school register l877 gives addresses in this way.
Towards the end of the l4th Century "Blundell" was added to the name of the village. It is very unusual for the village to take the name of the chief family rather than the reverse.
